During the lecture, we encoded the three boolean members single, rich, and female using one byte  b using the following rules as illustrated by this figure:

bit 7 bit 6 bit 5 bit 4 bit 3 bit 2 bit 1 bit 0
0 0 0 0 0 female rich single

- bit 0 is the least significant bit. bit 0 is set to 1 if the friend is single.

- bit 1  is set to 1 if the friend is rich.

- bit 2  is set to 1 if the friend is female.

Suppose that after encoding the three boolean members single, rich, and female of a friend f into a byte b, we get b = 0x5. Check all that apply about the friend f.

This exercise is about framing.

The following character encoding is used in a data link protocol:

X: 01000111   Y: 11110111   FLAG: 01111110         ESC:11100111

Show the bit sequence transmitted (in binary) for the four-character frame X Y ESC FLAG when "flag bytes with byte stuffing"  is used. Pay attention to the order. Fill in the following 8-bit groups. Some groups at the end may have less than 8 bits. If the group is empty, fill it with "-" (ONE minus character).

handler.question_text:
Matching.

Match each socket function call to the sequence it will appear on a Java TCP server. The first/earliest call is assigned the number 1. The earlier is a function call, the smaller is its assigned number. The statements must be compatible (i.e., use appropriate variables from earlier valid statements).

- If a call is NOT absolutely necessary, assign it the number 99. 

- If a call is NOT applicable to a TCP server socket, assign it the number 77.

- If two calls can be interchanged, assign them the same number.

Matching.

Match each socket function call to the sequence it will appear on a Java UDP server. The first/earliest call is assigned the number 1. The earlier is a function call, the smaller is its assigned number. The statements must be compatible (i.e., use appropriate variables from previous valid statements).

- If a call is NOT absolutely necessary, assign it the number 99. 

- If a call is NOT applicable to a UDP server socket, assign it the number 77.

- If two calls can be interchanged, assign them the same number.

handler.question_text:
Select the best answer.

The acknowledgement (ack) number in the TCP header is ___________________.
options: the number of the first byte in a segment
the number of the next expected byte (to be received)
the number of the next expected segment (to be received)
the number of the last byte in a segment
handler.answer: the number of the next expected byte (to be received)

handler.question_text:
Check all that apply.

Check all that apply to the problem of congestion control.
options: The transport layer requires information about the type of links used on intermediary nodes to perform congestion control
The transport layer on the end points communicates with any layer on the intermediary node to collect information to perform congestion control
The transport layer is active (running) on each  intermediary node to perform congestion control
It may be performed by the transport layer
answer: It may be performed by the transport layer

Wa: advertised value by the receiver

answer.answer: cwnd: a variable maintained by the sender to adapt to the network conditions
Wa: advertised value by the receiver

handler.question_text:
Check all that apply.

Check all true statements about the Weekly Pocket Money Problem.
options: Parents have a fixed allocation limit B for EACH child.
Some children may not ask for any pocket money  on some weeks
Some children know what their siblings requested and received the previous week.
Children are guaranteed to receive at least what they received the previous week.
A child may request and receive all the available weekly allocation B.
answer: Some children may not ask for any pocket money  on some weeks
A child may request and receive all the available weekly allocation B.

handler.question_text:
Matching.

This question is about how the Internet Protocol (IP) handles a packet P and decides where to deliver it.

Consider a device D with IP address 134.89.200.145/24. On Device D, IP is handed a packet P with a destination IP address 131.89.200.145. Provide the order in which IP on Device D will perform these actions. The earliest action must be assigned 1. Any action that is incorrect or is not performed must be assigned the number 0.
prompts: send Packet P to the device with IP address 134.89.200.145
check if Packet P is for Device D
ask ARP for a MAC address corresponding to IP Address 131.89.200.145
ask ARP for a MAC address corresponding to IP Address 131.89.200.1
hand Packet P to the appropriate protocol at the transport layer.
check if the IP destination address of Packet P is local
send Packet P to the device with IP address 134.89.200.128

answer.prompt: send Packet P to the device with IP address 134.89.200.145
check if Packet P is for Device D
ask ARP for a MAC address corresponding to IP Address 131.89.200.145
ask ARP for a MAC address corresponding to IP Address 131.89.200.1
hand Packet P to the appropriate protocol at the transport layer.
check if the IP destination address of Packet P is local
send Packet P to the device with IP address 134.89.200.128
